Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2007 12:26PM sherry7 wrote: Hi Dianne, I also had a single mastectomy.  I had a tram flap reconstruction that came up short for tummy tissue so I have a nice full hand size dent.  Prothetics annoyed it and me.  I was constantly afraid it would adjust without my consent or who knows what.  This is my solution I hope.  I am having an implant under the muscle that will lift the dent and fill it in as plastic surgeon will do some rearranging as well.  This will actually raise the skin and lymph vessels back up to an equal smooth runway instead of the severe drop off it had.  I wish you luck.  As for bras, I have stuck with leisure type bras, somehow they are fairly forgiving of lopsidedness. Isn't live a joy...good luck and take care, sherry

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2008 09:18PM sherry7 wrote: I am a lefty and also been with ignorant people who don't stop to think what they say may need to stay in their head and not let it out.  I had a family member tell me, Ah you just wanted a tummy tuck...  What the ?????  That was just the beginning.  I had a gal tell me gee she went right back to work after hers, just a few days, oh oh yeah she had a biopsey.  They don't know better.  Rather then say something stupid, don't say anything, ok???  A good retort to a stupid question is , what would your anwer be, how would they expect you to want to answer it?  Whey the world calls us survivors and warriors I don't think they still have the complete picture of what we are surviving even after tx.  Less words, more hugs works for me.  Take care, and I hope you have a smooth surgery and easy recovery, blessings dear...Sherry

Posts.Title: LE and prophylactic mastectomies althea jinky

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2008 08:01PM sherry7 wrote: Congrats on the positive news skyspyder.... However there is a big BUTT.  A discharge from a single nipple not both is a concern very real to be pursued as you are.  Yes it can be a ductal breast papilloma which will cause bloody discharge, but also discomfort and such.  If you have this discharge on one side only, don't let them waste a day to find out.  Get it biopseyed and we will pray your result is papilloma and they will take it out.  I had a discharge that started clear almost like breast milk that turned to a tea stain or coffee stain color, I showed my breast to the docs, they did ultra sounds and mammogram and it all came up fine.  But, heres the BUTT, I woke up a year after first notice of discharge with my breast swollen like a rock, hot, in pain and leaking like a nursing mom.  I called my breast specialist that I just hired and went in, she had me on the table in two days for lumpectomy.  Two weeks later I had a mastectomy and reconstruction.  My breast was so full of DCIS that I had no choice to keep the breast.  Now almost three years later I am looking at mets to my liver.  Be aggressive, build the team you most feel comfortable.  And the rest of us will pray for your next results to be a papilloma.  And, just in case if they say leave the papilloma and watch it, find another specialist.  They must not be left.  My docs assumed it was papilloma and put me off almost long enough for the dcis to run out of space, it would of had to break out somewhere if not stopped.  Your life, your day is precious.  Good luck, Sherry

Posts.Content: May 30, 2006 03:13AM sherry7 wrote: hi leechevier, nodes do not have to be involved during a surgery for breast cancer. I found this out personally six months after my mastectomy and reconstruction. Please don't look at it as automatic, its the luck of tha draw from what I see. Posts.Title: NYT story on lymphadema/lifting weight PJB Dejaboo

Posts.Content: May 28, 2006 06:36AM sherry7 wrote: Wow, I understand the rage and why. I too have developed Lymphedema following a simple mastectomy and tram reconstuction. I did not develope the LE until six months following my surgeries and I did not have any nodes touch or removed. I don't know what percentage that would of put me at but the reality is that I have LE. As a massage therapist, the diagnosis slammed a door on several styles of bodywork that I am trained to do. I am weak, it is painful, I do better early in the day and it gets cranky in the evenings. It has dictated my life almost more than the BC did. I had every intention of being strong afterwards and returning to the work I love. When the LE came about I had to look at my whole existance differently and still have tizzy fits when I think about all the things I still had plans on doing. My two year old grandson still wants to be picked up and he's over my limit. I can wash one window a day, mop one room floor a day. This is insane, I feel beaten before the day starts at times. What I am experimenting with toward helping LE is getting five cranial sacral sessions for five consectutive weeks, I have had two sessions and seem to be benefiting. I am a professional massage therapist and I will be happy to share the outcome if it continues to prove beneficial. I wish you all the best, don't give up, there is so much to learn about the magic of our bodies systems yet. Take care, a kindred spirit, Sherry
Posts.Title: NYT story on lymphadema/lifting weight PJB Dejaboo

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2007 08:03PM sherry7 wrote: first if your doubting your diagnosis and surgeon get an oncology breast surgeon.  They don't waste time knowing what to do.  The papilloma has to go.  Don't let them tell you differently.  By the way did you have a discharge from the "Papilloma" breast nipple?  What ever you do, make sure you feel in total trust of your team of docs, you will have many at times if you are treated for bc, but sounding like it isn't moving fast or aggressive, check around with the time you have.  You are in charge, remember that love and light to you, sherry7

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2007 09:11PM sherry7 wrote: Gracejon, I don't believe this is the correct professional for you.  They clearly know nothing about lymphedema so therefore she doesn't know what you go through.  I have a doc who totally understands my pain and does what he can to keep me comfortable.  I have what is called limb (arm and hand) and truncal (upper quadrant of body)lymhedema which is in the breast, underarm, and back behind armpit area.  Lymphedema reacts to the weather, I can tell when a storm is brewing and I wear my sleeve and gauntlet everyday, we are not to take days off, it puts us at risk.  Please get another opinion....good luck, sherry
